newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asia Product Swaps - Gas oil drifts sideways.
newsitem.headline: Asia Product Swaps - Gas oil drifts sideways.

text.p: Singapore gas oil swaps were unchanged late afternoon on Monday as the market looked fresh buying from a local trader to more than offset the bearish effects of a weak crude, industry sources said.
"The market is steady despite the weak crude as they are looking to Hin Leong to pick up the slack," one trader said.
The front month April gas oil was last quoted down at $26.45/$26.55 per barrel, down from Friday's $26.75/$26.85, brokers said.
April traded earlier in the day at $26.60, they said.
May gas oil was last quoted almost unchanged at $25.15/$25.35 per barrel in volatile trading, brokers said.
Brokers said May traded in the morning at $25.20 before edging down to $25.15 but picked up in the afternoon to trade at $25.25 before easing slightly.
Traders said the market is unfazed by the crude falls as they are counting on Hin Leong to continue buying for at least afew more days.

In a surprise move, on Friday, Hin Leong bought 520,000-barrels of diesel at $26.90-$26.90 per barrel for loading in end April/early May, taking its tally to almost eight million barrels since the buying spree started on March 3.
Traders said if the buying spate continued at such a rate, then the arrival of the huge arbitrage cargoes would make only a small dent in the market.

On Friday, May Brent crude lost 50 cents to close at $17.68 per barrel on the International Petroleum Exchange--taking its loses for the week to $1.43. Brent rebounded slightly on Monday to last trade at up 10 cents at $17.88.
The April jet fuel/gas oil regrade widened slightly to last quote at -1.00/-80 cents, down from Friday's -0.90/-0.70, brokers said.
Fuel oil swaps were unchanged with May last quoted at $97.00/$98.00, and traded earlier in the day at $96.75, brokers said.
